title: Géza Gyimóthy
text:
Géza Gyimóthy (born 12 March 1952) is a former <a href="Hungary">Hungarian</a> politician, who served as one of the <a href="Deputy%20Speaker%20of%20the%20National%20Assembly%20of%20Hungary">Deputy Speakers of the National Assembly of Hungary</a> from 18 June 1998 to 19 September 2001.
Political career.
Gyimóthy joined <a href="Hungarian%20Democratic%20Forum">Hungarian Democratic Forum</a> (MDF) in 1988 and formed the party's basic organization in <a href="Tata%2C%20Hungary">Tata</a>. However he quit the party one year later, because he considered the party's leadership was compromising. After that he became a member of the <a href="Independent%20Smallholders%2C%20Agrarian%20Workers%20and%20Civic%20Party">Independent Smallholders, Agrarian Workers and Civic Party</a> (FKGP) on 12 January 1990. He served as chairman of the party in his birthplace between 1990 and 1991. He was a strong supporter of <a href="J%C3%B3zsef%20Torgy%C3%A1n">József Torgyán</a>.
He unsuccessfully ran for the parliamentary seat for <a href="Kom%C3%A1rom-Esztergom%20County">Komárom-Esztergom County</a> 5th Constituency in the <a href="1990%20Hungarian%20parliamentary%20election">elections in 1990</a>. He became Deputy Chairman of the Independent Smallholders Party in July 1994. He was elected to a member of the <a href="National%20Assembly%20of%20Hungary">National Assembly</a> during the <a href="1994%20Hungarian%20parliamentary%20election">1994 elections</a> from the party's National List. He was appointed Deputy Chairman of the Committee on Agriculture.
After the <a href="1998%20Hungarian%20parliamentary%20election">1998 elections</a>, Gyimóthy became a deputy speaker of the parliament. He frequently used yellow and red cards to rebuke of MPs. In 2000, former <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Hungary">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Gyula%20Horn">Gyula Horn</a> called FKGP leader Torgyán as "Pubi", that is why Gyimóthy called him to order. Horn answered: "This is offensive? Do not be silly, Géza!" This moment became a political anecdote in Hungary.
In 2001-2002 the FKGP split into two parts and Gyimóthy's relation with the Party Chairman decayed. He was a candidate for the position of <a href="Minister%20of%20Agriculture%20%28Hungary%29">Minister of Agriculture</a>, when Torgyán resigned, however he was expelled from the party by Torgyán. As a result, Gyimóthy also lost his legislative deputy speaker function. After the failure <a href="2002%20Hungarian%20parliamentary%20election">2002 Hungarian parliamentary election</a> for the FKGP, he retired from the politics.
Trivia.
Géza Gyimóthy was one of the founders of the "Szená-torok", the official choir of the National Assembly of Hungary.
